title: Time and the Rani
dialogue_triumphs: 'Leave the girl, it's the man I want.'
'Really, this is not the place for double entendres.'
goofs: The Rani can check that the Doctor's hearts are beating simply by placing a hand on his chest.
The Doctor is able to check Mel's pulse with his thumbs.
Without appearing to make any adjustments to the TARDIS the Rani is able to patch Urak's vision straight into the TARDIS scanner.
She is able to shoot down the TARDIS as one would any old passing spacecraft.
In order to release the Lakertyans from the Rani's deadly bracelets, the Doctor and Mel use a fibre-optic cable to complete an electrical circuit.
Tetraps have eyes in the front, sides and back of their heads. Why, then, do they need to turn their heads when looking for something?
The opening title sequence for episode four is flawed, with McCoy's face hardly visible.
When the TARDIS crash-lands Mel is barely stunned, but it's enough to trigger the Doctor's regeneration.

technobabble: 'The heat radiation from the catalyst was of high frequency.'

'In the aftermath of the explosion, helium-2 will fuse with the upper zones of the Lakertyan atmosphere to form a shell of chronons… In the same milliseconds as the chronon shell is being formed, the hot-house effect of the gamma rays will cause the primate cortex of the brain to go into chain reaction, multiplying until the gap between shell and planet is filled.'

untold_adventures: By the next story the Doctor has taken Einstein and the others home.
additional_notes: This is the only Doctor Who story to mention Elvis.
bottom_line: 'I have the loyhargil! Nothing can stop me now!' If it was truncated into three episodes, and came with a self-lobotomising kit, this might have been a passable adventure romp. But it isn't.
